awd_titl_txt: Miniaturized Frequency Combs for Precision Radial Velocity Characterization of Exoplanets
awd_abstract_narration:
This effort is to develop small, low power, robust spectral rulers called frequency combs that astronomers can use to help measure the motion of stars. In doing so, they can identify planets orbiting those stars and gain information about the mass of the planets. This research enables tantalizing discoveries about the existence and nature of other planets, ultimately helping us to search for other worlds like our own.

This research is to advance the instrumental capabilities for Precision Radial Velocity (PRV) observations of exoplanet-hosting stars by creating broad, octave-spanning comb spectra in the 0.8 micron to greater than 2 micron region at GHz repetition rates through soliton formation in silica microresonators. This will be accomplished by balancing Raman and dispersive wave effects in the microresonators, and using pulsed excitation of the microcomb to improve pumping efficiency. The resulting combs will be used as low power, compact calibration sources on high-resolution spectrographs installed at ground-based observatories. Advances in PRV instrumentation can enable the identification of Earth-sized planets in the Habitable Zones of some of the nearest stars to the sun.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this program is to develop an alternative calibration source technology for spectrographs used in the Precision Radial Velocity (PRV) detection and characterization of exoplanets. This technology aims to be compact, low-power, reliable, and long-lasting. The calibration source explored is based on a miniature optical frequency comb (OFC) fabricated on a silicon chip. The OFC device uses a high-Q microresonator that is optically pumped, a key platform for generating OFCs through dissipative Kerr solitons. Typically, solitons are generated by pumping the resonator with a continuous wave (CW) laser, but the conversion efficiency between the generated soliton and CW pump power is typically less than 1%, due to the minimal temporal overlap between the CW laser and the ultra-short soliton pulse within the cavity. Also, operation of the devices at wavelengths approaching visible bands is desirable for PRV systems. However, this is challenging on account of large normal dispersion of nearly all dielectrics in the near-visible bands. This normal dispersion inhibits formation of solitons. 

One objective of this program was to investigate a novel method of resonator pumping using pulsed lasers, which resulted in significantly improved efficiencies, reaching up to 54%. Our research also led to a deeper understanding and modeling of the efficiency limits of this approach. In addition to pulsed pumping, we explored a new platform for microcomb generation in both the near-infrared and visible regions, offering full CMOS compatibility. A compact, packaged device based on this platform has been developed and successfully tested in the lab. Additionally, a resonator design, operating in both the 1-micron and 0.78-micron bands, has been developed. The resonator is formed as a compound resonator that allows dispersion engineering to overcome the inherent normal dispersion of the dielectric (in this case silica and silicon- nitride). The development of shorter wavelength (<1 micron) OFCs could have a major impact on astronomical instruments used for Extreme Precision Radial Velocity (EPRV) measurements to detect earth-sized planets orbiting sun-like stars. Such searches are best carried out at visible wavelengths where currently available frequency standards are large and cumbersome.
